text: Ok, so I’ve roughly talked about
jobs and career development in AWS.
Now let’s turn to Mark.
Hello, everyone, this is Mark.

Thank you, Tim, for talking
about AWS Support.

As for myself, I’ve been
working for AWS Support
for nearly four years.

Initially I was a
Cloud Support Engineer.

What makes me different from Tim
is that, just as mentioned,

I keep staying on the
engineer path.
Let me talk about my last job.
I was in charge of R&D

in a security control company
called VIVOTEK.

I worked on the underlying
network and process development
for IP cameras.

I also built back-end
servers with Golang,

including RESTful
API servers, or
WebRTC signal server.
In Amazon, I am in charge of
network content and CDN services.
I also handle WAF issues,

such as
SQL injection,
or cross-site script,
or DDOS related issues.
Ok.
Wait a second, ok.
Now, as for me,

I am actually a
Cloud Support Engineer
all along this career.
So I want to use the

job grade system for our
Cloud Support Engineers to
share with you something that
many people are curious about.
What do cloud support engineers do?
Let’s begin from CSA on the left.
CSA actually refers to
Cloud Support Associate.

The CSA role is mostly
for those with 1-2 years of work
experience or university graduates.
They’re not proficient enough.

So we would ask them to
handle basic cases to
enhance their proficiency.
We will not let CSAs handle
enterprise support customers.
I want to add something
regarding the enterprise support.
There are different plans for
the AWS technical support.
There are mainly three paid plans,
Developer,
Business, and Enterprise.

For enterprise clients,
they are usually bigger in size,

and their issues are more
diversified and more complicated.
So at the CSA stage,
we focus on single-aspect services,
or more basic technical issues.

When CSAs gain sufficient
level of proficiency,
they will be
assessed in our internal process to
decide on the promotion to CSE,
which means Cloud Support Engineer.

This process usually takes
about 6 months to a year.
CSE is a stage where you can
quickly gain lots of knowledge.
As a CSE, you will encounter
various types of cases,
no matter the severity level.
As we’ve mentioned, we

offer different Support Plans.
The cases submitted by clients also
have different severity levels,
from 1 to 5.
5 is the most urgent.

For level 5, we usually
respond within 15 minutes.
At this point, CSEs will handle
various severe or not severe issues
or issues requiring more skills.
They will quickly gain knowledge.
They will also gain experience

in one service within
their own technical area.

When you accumulate enough
knowledge in one
single service,
you’ll need to take the Subject-
Matter Expert (SME) internal exam
and certification, which Tim
has just mentioned.
Once you pass this exam, you will
be deemed an expert in this service.

For example,
I am actually an
SME for ELB, meaning
Elastic Load Balancing.

After passing the exam and
becoming an ELB expert,
I will get more challenging tasks.
Because I might do some

Support Ops tasks,
as we just mentioned.

I will also get
ELB cases

that other engineers
are not able to handle, and
they will escalate them to me.
Aside from these challenges, we’ll
also get more opportunities,

because I can join the
global ELB forum, where you

can find Support Engineers for
global ELB SMEs,

and also our
ELB development team.
We hold regular discussions, or

we have training meetings,
every week or every month,

to understand the
latest client feedback on ELB,
and the latest ELB technology,
and when to launch new features.
And in addition to these,

we are also in charge of
global education training

to help our
Support Engineers get familiar
with this ELB product.
So besides more challenges,

you also have the opportunity to
know more about this service.
Other than this part of job,
as a CSE
you will work as a Support Ops,
like what we just mentioned.
You may need to handle
some escalated cases,
When a case is escalated,
it usually means this case
is in fact more urgent.

The client may have a
production plan

And you need to have
more expertise and know
how to reassure the clients, and
let the clients know how we

are helping them solve their
issues in the fastest possible way.
So you may need to work with
several internal teams to
quickly find the solution to
the client’s issue.
After this process,
you will enter the next level,
what we called CSE II internally.
During CSE II,
besides a single area of expertise,
you’ll be proficient in more areas,
and more services.

Specifically, you will not be only
specialized in ELB service.
You may also be specialized in,
for example, it’s network for me.
For network, I may be specialized
in BDOS, for example,

or WAF,
or other technical areas.
Why do we want people in CSE II
to be proficient in more areas?

It’s because for a
typical client case,
it may actually involve

various types of
AWS network services.

For example, the client’s
structure may contain

Crown Font CDN
at the front end,
an ELB in the middle,
an EKS at the back,
which can be a container.

When there is an issue
with the client’s services,
if you know these
three elements very well,

you can actually see
the big picture on
this issue so that
you can solve it more quickly.

We expect people in CSE II to
be able to do this kind of tasks.

When you are specialized in
more than one or two services,
you will eventually become a
Senior Cloud Support Engineer.

As a Senior Cloud
Support Engineer, you will be
specialized in the entire domain,
such as the network domain.
You will also be in charge of tech
issues without any clear direction.
By this time, you will also join
some global projects that

aim at improving the
Cloud Support Engineer’s

ability to serve some of
the clients’ projects.

So after the introduction of
the CSE job grades,
to describe the CSE job
in one sentence,

I would say it helps
our AWS users to know more
how to use AWS.

Why is that?
Because there are actually various
types of clients on AWS Cloud.

As mentioned, we have
Developer and Enterprise clients,

no matter whether
they are small or big,
and no matter their industries.

For example, we’ve got
e-commerce and blockchain clients,

and many other clients that use
our AWS services.

And AWS Support aims to help
the clients understand what
services they should use,

or what the best practice is
for the circumstance where
they use the service.
We get this question:
do you only do troubleshooting?
Actually it’s not true.

In addition to
troubleshooting,

we also help clients
with architecture planning.
For example,

we also helped an
online ticketing system to
optimize its DynamoDB to

greatly reduce the
latency for ticket sales.
We also helped a flash sales
website to figure out what the
bottleneck was during flash sales,

and helped them plan for some
resources in advance so that the
flash sales can run more smoothly.

You can see there is a
QR Code here below.
It is linked to some of

our customers’
testimonies.

Scan it to read them if
you are interested.

The middle one is linked to
our support plan subscription.
As I’ve mentioned earlier,

we have four
support plans.

If you want to know about
these support plans,
scan the one in the middle.
I think the DDoS Case Sharing on
the right side is very worthwhile.
It’s our Cloud Support Engineers

sharing how we helped
the clients solve their
DDoS issues, and

how to help them mitigate
DDoS attacks, and

how we helped them bring
the service back to normal.
Ok, now that we know

the scope of duties for
Cloud Support Engineers,
let’s look at the technical depth.
I want to start with
the things that people would

want to point out when they
first start their job here.
The first one is:
Only after starting working here

do I realize why they asked such
difficult questions at the interview.

Take my past work experience in
R&D for example.
At my previous job, I was

actually very focused on
how to write the code well, and
how to make the code scalable.
But when I want to use a protocol,

for example, a TCP
or a WebSocket,

I actually don’t need to know
how its underlying protocol works.

I usually only need to know
how to call this API,

or how to use
a specific function to call it.
But when you start working here,

you realize that you need to solve
a technical issue for the clients.
For example,

if a client says that he cannot
access a certain EC2 today,
which is our virtual machine, we
may need him to intercept packets,
or collect HAR files.
In order to intercept packets,
we actually need to understand
how PCP actually works.

Because only when you understand
how PCP actually works,
can you analyze these packets.

Then you are able to help
the clients understand what

the issue is, and
what he should do to solve it.

Second one, there are always
new services and features in AWS
every day, more than I can learn.
Indeed, when I first started here,
there were only over 100 services.

But today at AWS
we have actually

more than 200 services.
The number has doubled.
Besides increase of services,
the features in each service
have also been evolving.
So there are always new customer
scenarios or new features to learn.
The third one is,
when I call customer service,
I feel like a difficult customer

because we are used to
handle things based on the AWS
Support standards.
In fact,

the goal of AWS Support,
even of the entire Amazon,
is to become the Earth’s
most customer-centric company.

So when we make a decision
on the Support side, or
a decision on the Product side,
most of our decisions are
based on customer feedback,
or ideas from customers, so that
our technology can keep evolving.

Ok, next we will
take a look at FAQs.
Do cloud support engineers focus
only on infrastructure?
As you can see,

Tim and I are not really
experts in infrastructure.
I am more in Browsing Networking
I am in the development.
Tim is more familiar with Big Data.
So it’s not strictly required that

you need to know, for example,
the underlying networking, or
that you must be proficient in
how to assemble machines, etc.
What skills do candidates need to have?
Do they need to have cloud knowledge?

Actually when we
look at the candidate profiles,
each profile is different.
If you have some cloud knowledge,
it would be a plus.
But it’s ok if you don’t.
We actually prefer people with
an in-depth knowledge in one
specific area to someone who has
extensive, not in-depth, knowledge.
You need to like to solve
issues through learning.

For example,
what we like more is a person

who is specialized in HTTP,
or maybe PCP, but

who may not be familiar
with DNS, for example,

or with the underlying VPN,
but it is not a problem,
because you’re really good at HTTP.

What we are looking for is someone
who enjoys in-depth learning,

or who likes to dig deep before
finding a solution to an issue.
Ok.
